So there I was, watching some baseball on TV. The San Francisco Giants were playing the Los Angeles Dodgers. The announcers started talking about the successes the Dodgers had had over the years.
 
 The camera panned to a stadium balcony which displayed the years the Dodgers had won the MLB pennant. Each placard had the words "World Champions" above the year. 
 
 Arrrgh!! What the hell is wrong with Americans? Why do they have to call the winners of their national sports competitions the "World Champions"? Let's get one thing straight - they're NOT. Being the best in America makes you the American champions. You have to beat teams in an INTERNATIONAL competition to be the World Champions of something. Why do Americans think otherwise?
 
 Now sure, I've thought about just how good an American football or baseball team has to be to win their respective national competition. And sure, MAYBE it's 'safe to assume' that no national team from any other country would beat them; but... so what? In Australia we play Australian Rules Football, and it's a safe bet that no-one from any other country would beat the annual AFL Grand Final winners. But they're still just the Australian champions. It's not like they beat Paraguay or something! I guarantee if they called themselves the World Champions, the Australian public would laugh in their faces.
 
 Around the world, dozens of countries play each other in truly international contests, in which America is mostly conspicuously absent! There are TRUE World Cups in soccer, rugby (both types), and cricket. Does America feel so completely impotent and inadequate because they can't win on the real world stage? Is this why they have to somehow console themselves? Is that it? Are they just sad? Or are they cocky? Or are they insular?
 
 Are you an American? What do YOU think? Should the USA knock it off already?

Well I'm excited.
 
 The baseball WORLD SERIES is well under way, between the industrialized nation of Philadelphia, and the tiny state of Tampabay (I think the telly has a typo).
 
 Trade talks have been precarious between these two countries as they've strived to address the imbalance of their GDP's. It's to be hoped that this international sporting contest can bring them closer together, and that it won't drive a wedge in their global relations.
